lines.text: Pulley, lever, wedge, wheel/axle, screw, inclined plane
Ratio of force produced to force applied

secText:
Essential Question:
How can we measure the efficiency of a machine?

Enduring Understandings:
1. [OBJ:expsec_i979:Simple machines] change the direction of force. Examples of simple machines are pulleys, levers, wedges, wheels/axles, screws, and inclined planes.
2. [OBJ:expsec_i980:Mechanical advantage] can be measured by dividing the force produced by the force applied. The [OBJ:expsec_i981:amount of work] done on the machine does not change the amount of work done by the machine.
3. The [OBJ:expsec_i982:efficiency of a machine] is measured by dividing the work output of the machine by the work input of the machine.
